My Biography



I got introduced into the world of information technology as a very curious teenager who had just graduated high school. I grew up in a third world country where owning a personal computer was not so common and I was considered privileged to be a child from a family who owned a desktop computer. My father brought it home as a gift to me when a friend who didn’t need it any more gave him. It was with that computer that I learned how to type and very occasionally, when we would buy access to connect with 3g, surf the internet.

When my family immigrated to the united states, our neighbors and church members welcomed us and gave us gifts to make the transition easier for us. One of the gifts I received was a laptop from a family friend for me to use for school. It was with that laptop that I began to find the answers to questions I always had. One search result for the question to “how are websites made” led me to Code Academy where I enrolled in various web development courses and began to design websites. I was in awe when the code I wrote ran and rendered a static html page. I continued to take many classes, increasing my knowledge.

When the time came to choose a community college major, I wanted to study computer science, but I decided not to because I had the fear of failing since I didn’t have any computer science education in high school and the I felt the little knowledge I had was just a drop in the ocean of the completer science. I choose the next choice I had—Accounting, which aligned with my love of numbers, business knowledge and processes. Despite this, I remained passionate and continued to design websites and learn about computers.

Although I did very well in my accounting curriculum, when it became time to transfer to a four-year college, I decided to go for a major that would receive my credits from community college and allow me to continue in a major where I could learn and do more with technology. I decided to major in Business Analytics and Information Technology (BAIT) which was the only technology focused major in the business school.
